factoid: The ice bore him.
The ice swayed and creaked.
The ice would give way under a cannon.
The ice would give way under a crowd.
The ice would give way under his weight alone.
The men looked at him.
The men pressed to the bank.
The men hesitated to step onto the ice.
The general was on horseback at the entrance to the dam.
The general raised his hand.
The general opened his mouth to address Dólokhov.
A cannon ball hissed so low above the crowd.
Everyone ducked.
The cannon ball flopped into something moist.
The general fell from his horse.
The general fell into a pool of blood.
Nobody gave the general a look.
Nobody thought of raising the general.
Innumerable voices shouted “Get onto the ice, over the ice! Go on! Turn! Don’t you hear? Go on!” after the ball struck the general.
The men shouted without knowing why.
One of the hindmost guns that was going onto the dam turned onto the ice.
Crowds of soldiers from the dam began running onto the frozen pond.
The ice gave way under one of the foremost soldiers.
One leg of that soldier slipped into the water.
The soldier tried to right himself.
The soldier fell up to his waist.
The nearest soldiers shrank back.
The gun driver stopped his horse.
Shouts “Onto the ice, why do you stop? Go on! Go on!” came from behind.
Cries of horror were heard in the crowd.
The soldiers near the gun waved their arms.
The soldiers near the gun beat the horses to make them turn.
The soldiers near the gun made the horses move on.
The horses moved off the bank.
The ice collapsed in a great mass.
Some forty men were on the ice.
Some forty men dashed forward.
Some forty men dashed backward.
The men drowned one another.
Cannon balls continued to whistle.
Cannon balls flopped onto the ice.
Cannon balls flopped into the water.
Cannon balls often landed among the crowd that covered the dam, the pond, and the bank.
Prince Andrew Bolkónski fell on the Pratzen Heights with the flagstaff in his hand.
Prince Andrew Bolkónski was bleeding profusely.
Prince Andrew Bolkónski was unconsciously uttering a gentle, piteous, and childlike moan.
Toward evening Prince Andrew Bolkónski ceased moaning.
Toward evening Prince Andrew Bolkónski became quite still.
Prince Andrew Bolkónski did not know how long his unconsciousness lasted.
Prince Andrew Bolkónski suddenly felt that he was alive.
Prince Andrew Bolkónski suffered from a burning, lacerating pain in his head.
Prince Andrew Bolkónski's first thought was “Where is it, that lofty sky that I did not know till now, but saw today?”
Prince Andrew Bolkónski thought “And I did not know this suffering either.”
Prince Andrew Bolkónski thought “Yes, I did not know anything, anything at all till now. But where am I?”
Prince Andrew Bolkónski listened and heard the sound of approaching horses.
Prince Andrew Bolkónski heard voices speaking French.
Prince Andrew Bolkónski opened his eyes.
Above him was the same lofty sky with clouds that had risen and were floating still higher.
Between the clouds gleamed blue infinity.
Prince Andrew Bolkónski did not turn his head.
Prince Andrew Bolkónski did not see those who had ridden up and stopped near him.
It was Napoleon accompanied by two aides-de-camp.
Napoleon had given final orders to strengthen the batteries firing at the Augesd Dam.
Napoleon was looking at the killed and wounded left on the field.
Napoleon remarked “Fine men!”.
Napoleon looked at a dead Russian grenadier.
The dead Russian grenadier had his face buried in the ground.
The dead Russian grenadier had a blackened nape.
The dead Russian grenadier lay on his stomach.
The dead Russian grenadier had an already stiffened arm flung wide.
An adjutant said “The ammunition for the guns in position is exhausted, Your Majesty.”
The adjutant had come from the batteries that were firing at Augesd.
Napoleon said “Have some brought from the reserve.”
Napoleon went on a few steps.
Napoleon stopped before Prince Andrew.
Prince Andrew lay on his back with the flagstaff that had been dropped beside him.
The flag had already been taken by the French as a trophy.
Napoleon said “That’s a fine death!”.
Napoleon gazed at Bolkónski.
